points.point: A class in Kotlin can only have one primary constructor and one or more secondary constructors.
A class is public and final and with a public zero-param constructor by default.
The Functions and the Properties of a class are final by default and must be open to overriding.
An open member can not be private.
When a class defines a primary constructor, all secondary constructors must either:
sub_points: Directly delegate to the primary constructor using the this keyword.
Indirectly delegate to the primary constructor by chaining through another secondary constructor, which itself eventually delegates to the primary constructor.

points.point: During the initialization of an instance, the initializer blocks are executed in the same order as they appear in the class body, interleaved with the property initializers.
Members that declared in the companion object block must be called by the class name without instantiating.
sub_points: Members declared inside a companion object are similar to static members in Java.
You cannot access companion object members using an instance of the class.
Class members can access the private members of the corresponding companion object.
